content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It was quite fun! Easy enough to understand the desired output and yet challenging enough to make the loops a bit elegant.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I'm of the opinion we can never have too many easy puzzles like this.  I work with young people learning to code and this is a perfect puzzle for any of them.  As for us older folk, the challenge of creating a concise, yet elegant, solution is definitely present here.  Great job @Lisa-Has-Ideas!

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This puzzle is clearly an easy one, but too long for a clash, and very fun to solve. The statement is very clear and well detailed. There are many tests. Nice !

Hi Lisa-Has-Ideas. I have to google Pete Buttigieg to know who is this man. OK he's the Secretary of Transportation of the United States. So i think you should start your statement with "You are a US citizen and the ..." something like this for those who are not from the USA.

Nice puzzle Lisa-Has-Ideas.  I only had one spot where the wording felt a tiny bit less than smooth:

"so all that input will be on a single line of string."

I think you could eliminate the words "of string" or change it to say "will be in a single string of data". For me, the words "line of string" felt like a little speed bump on an otherwise very smooth highway of reading.

Goal section
* Suggest to format "left" and "right" as constants and remove the quotation marks.

Thanks.

Thank you.  Done :)

I appreciate how your feedback wording was consistent with the theme too ... a speedbump !!

Right, good suggestion.  I changed it to his full title "United States Secretary of Transportation".

Pete ran for USA president and had lots of supporters (including me).  Hopefully he will run again, but for now he's in charge of an 1 Trillion dollar infrastructure plan.  He is Harvard-educated, a musician and speaks 7 languages.  He is a uniter of parties (for example, the only democrat was regularly appears on Fox News), and IMHO the great hope for the future of America.  So I'm glad I made you look him up :)

I've been thinking about this off and on for a week. Is it best to use Pete's name specifically in an academic exercise?  It seems like the problem should maybe be generic.  I.e. The Secretary of Transportation has asked you...

Your puzzle will most likely long outlive Pete's career. 50 or 100 years from now, Codingamers will hopefully still be doing your puzzle.  Who knows where Pete will be or what will have come of him?

I live in Denver.  I like Pete - I do think my governor has a better shot at the oval office.üòâ  The only reason I haven't hit the approve button is because I can't make up my mind how I feel about a specific political figure's name in an academic exercise.

I hear ya.   Let me plead my case:
Pete Buttigieg (unlike a generic secretary of transportation) is famously a minimalist.
Therefore all the inputs being together on one line fits beautifully.  Teasing out the inputs adds a bit of needed complexity to an otherwise pretty simple puzzle.

In a dozen years it will be charmingly nostalgic.

I changed it to just Pete and removed United States.  That‚Äôs better for the global audience and I think addresses your concern.  Thanks for that feedback.

Hopefully that ‚Äúgreen-lights‚Äù it for approval, and there will be no more ‚Äúconstruction delays‚Äù üòä

Thank you.  I just hit the "approve" button, so feel free to tell me enough is enough, but I might reword the beginning like this:

Pete, the Secretary of Transportation, has asked you...

"Secretary of Transportation Pete" made me think of nicknames and cartoon characters such as Pistol Pete and Yosemite Sam. I'm not a huge basketball fan, so I have no idea where I even heard of Pistol Pete.

Ha, I mean on one level you are absolutely right.  

But since he goes by Mayor Pete and now ‚ÄúSecretary Pete‚Äù‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs a ‚Äúnod to those in the know‚Äù that it is indeed Pete Buttigieg
